Darth Sidious cultivated the image of Sheev Palpatine, an honest and trustworthy politician prior to his ascension as Emperor.

 

Prior to the Galactic Empire, Darth Sidious was careful to put on a charade, presenting himself as a grandfatherly gentleman and a servant of the public good. When in character, he often spoke of himself with great modesty and maintained only as much luxury as was expected of someone of his stature.[[306]](#cite_note-explEPII_Palpatine-306) However, Sidious was, in fact, a skilled manipulator and strategist, having orchestrated countless events in the galaxy, from the Invasion of Naboo to the Clone Wars, while deceiving the Jedi, Senate, Republic, and even the Separatists, with the sole aim of increasing his own power.[[9]](#cite_note-SWEPalpatine-9) Even when something occurred that he did not initially plan for, the Sith Lord demonstrated that he was as adept at improvisation as he was at plotting,[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1) continuing to play his long game—a smart game—for power.[[29]](#cite_note-Queen's_Peril-29) Sometimes he indulged in a simple fantasy by imagining lighting the Senate Building aflame, which he enjoyed thinking about because it would force everyone inside to run in panic while he watched. Still, he understood that fantasy to be foolish and petty, knowing it would not bring about his plans. Almost as satisfying to the Sith Lord was watching the Senate grapple with the Clone Wars and his new political powers.[[25]](#cite_note-Queen's_Hope-25)

Palpatine was someone who enjoyed the finer things of life.[[72]](#cite_note-FF_117_Palpatine-72) During the Republic Era, Sidious did not feel the need to hide in the lower levels of Coruscant, which he developed a personal dislike of. Instead, he preferred to remain amongst those who thought they were safe from the dark side. He would find the "weak points" of these places, ensuring the dark side took the light's place where-ever it was fading. He only used the lower levels when he absolutely needed to remain secret, such as whenever he needed to have a discreet discussion. Furthermore, he preferred to speak to his pawns via hologram, knowing that his in person presence could be overwhelming to people like Nute Gunray. He instead kept that advantage saved for whenever one of his "allies" was failing him. In public, as Senator of Naboo, he portrayed himself in a perfect state of blandness, looking interested in whatever was said nearby but never showing his true face. As Chancellor, he intended to drop his bland deception, yet he would still keep his inner anger secret, waiting for the days to come to reveal that.[[29]](#cite_note-Queen's_Peril-29)

After his ascension to Galactic Emperor,[[32]](#cite_note-SWEYoda-32) he essentially dropped his public persona and started living as Sidious full-time.[[36]](#cite_note-SWESidious-36) Despite this, very few people other than Vader and some Royal Guard members knew that the Emperor was a Sith, as he took great pains to hide his capabilities.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178) Even Grand Moff Wilhuff Tarkin, perhaps Sidious' most trusted servant besides Vader, only suspected that Sidious was a Sith.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15) Sidious also regarded Gallius Rax as a confidante and allowed Rax to address him as "Sheev."[[19]](#cite_note-Aftermath:_Life_Debt-19) Freed from having to portray his gentle alter-ego, Sidious allowed his true personality, one of great cruelty and sadism, to occasionally shine through in ways that were obvious even to the most sycophantic of his servants. This caused many of those who worked closely with him, such as Senator Orn Free Taa and some of the Empire's intelligence chiefs, to greatly fear him.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178) Sidious was also known to loath ostentation and luxury.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15)

 [![Sidious concealed his nature as a Sith by cultivating the facade of a politician devoted to the ideals of the Republic.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/6/64/InSidiousSmile-Revival.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20121010231653) [![Sidious concealed his nature as a Sith by cultivating the facade of a politician devoted to the ideals of the Republic.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/6/64/InSidiousSmile-Revival.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20121010231653)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/6/64/InSidiousSmile-Revival.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20121010231653) 

Sidious concealed his nature as a Sith by cultivating the facade of a politician devoted to the ideals of the Republic.

 

Among Sidious' most effective traits was his deeply manipulative nature, manipulating and deceiving both the Jedi and Separatists, seducing many parties with promises of power, prize, or even salvation to further his agenda.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) He enjoyed the rush manipulating others to his will gave him.[[25]](#cite_note-Queen's_Hope-25) Even so, he was annoyed by when his pawns, such as Nute Gunray, failed to understand the grand scope of his plans.[[29]](#cite_note-Queen's_Peril-29) Nevertheless, he successfully coerced Anakin Skywalker into becoming Darth Vader by promising to save his beloved, Padmé Amidala,[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) attempted to sweet talk Bridger with being able to reunite with his deceased parents by altering fate[[221]](#cite_note-FRAF-221) and also tried to push Luke Skywalker into murdering his father so they could rule the galaxy together.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) While trying to steer Bridger, he displayed himself in his public personality via hologram, showing himself as benign and polite. Once Bridger frustrated his plans, his true malignant self was revealed as he had underestimated the boy's hatred for the Empire and devotion to the Rebellion and new-found rebel family.[[221]](#cite_note-FRAF-221) Likewise, when Sidious tried to motivate Luke into killing his father upon momentarily embracing the dark side of the Force, the young Skywalker desisted due to his compassion for his father; his Jedi teachings.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4)

Sidious saw his allies as pawns that he could use for his grand plan, and was more than willing to dispose them if they no longer served a purpose. He kept his allies as long as they served his purpose, but cut them loose when their purpose was over. He never actually cared for any one of his allies. He betrayed countless allies, including Darth Plagueis,[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Maul,[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1) Dooku, the Separatist Council, and Vader.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Sidious considered his disposal of Maul justified by his former apprentice's inability to be good enough, even once referring to Maul as an idiot.[[270]](#cite_note-Hidden_Empire_1-270) The way he betrayed Dooku, not only showed that he never really cared for him, but also showed how he was always one step ahead. While acknowledging to Vader that he was the ideal apprentice,[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) that did not stop Sidious from later trying to replace him with Luke.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) Sidious believed that Vader was incapable of surpassing him and taking the position of Sith Master. He believed that he would always be one of the Sith Lords that made up the Rule of Two, even laughing at the thought of the possibility of Vader becoming the master and Luke the apprentice.[[307]](#cite_note-Vader_2020_47-307) At the end of the day, Sidious was only out for himself.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)

Sidious considered his manipulation to be a sharp knife that, when stabbed into another, took time for that individual to notice, only realizing they had spread what he deemed to be the infection of his manipulation when it was too late. Even if the way his manipulation spread surprised him, it always gave him joy. Manipulation was ultimately his favorite way to grow his power.[[25]](#cite_note-Queen's_Hope-25) Sidious was known for being hypocritical and arrogant; whilst he told Yoda that his arrogance had blinded him when the Jedi Master confronted him, he had previously declared himself to be the Senate when Windu tried to arrest him.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Even shortly before his second death years later, Sidious declared himself to be all the Sith while trying to finish off with his Jedi granddaughter.[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7)

 [![Darth Sidious was an ambitious Sith Lord who sought to destroy the Jedi Order and the Galactic Republic they served.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/01/Darktimesbegin.png/revision/latest?cb=20121213095432) [![Darth Sidious was an ambitious Sith Lord who sought to destroy the Jedi Order and the Galactic Republic they served.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/01/Darktimesbegin.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20121213095432)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/01/Darktimesbegin.png/revision/latest?cb=20121213095432) 

Darth Sidious was an ambitious Sith Lord who sought to destroy the Jedi Order and the Galactic Republic they served.

 

After toppling the Republic and shedding his benevolent persona, Sidious essentially disappeared from public life and left most of the day-to-day affairs of the Empire in the hands of the [Imperial Ruling Council](/wiki/Imperial_Ruling_Council "Imperial Ruling Council"). His absence did not go unnoticed by the citizenry of the Empire, and rumors began to circulate that the Jedi assassination attempt had not only resulted in his disfigurement but in the death of the sanguine politician that he had once been. In order to quash the gossip and rumor-mongering, the Ruling Council took to dispatching skycar processions in Imperial Center in an effort to make it appear as though Sidious still moved about in public.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15)

From his secured position[[31]](#cite_note-TROS_VD-31) as Emperor, Sidious devoted most of his time to study and meditation, often in the ancient Sith shrine situated beneath the Imperial Palace. Wishing to rule his Empire for eternity, Sidious launched numerous inquiries into the topic of immortality. One of the most notorious of these was [Project Blackwing](/wiki/Project_Blackwing "Project Blackwing"); an attempt to unlock the secrets of immortality through Sith alchemy, but the project ended in failure.[[308]](#cite_note-Commander-308) However, Sidious' true goal was ultimately to discover a way to use the dark side to manipulate reality itself, and with that power, not only achieve what he termed "mere immortality" but acquire the ability to reshape the galaxy and its people to his satisfaction. Whether or not Sidious made any significant progress in obtaining this goal is not known however, as he would have needed Vader's assistance to perform the sorts of rituals he had in mind.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15) During the Imperial Era, Darth Sidious sought to gain access to the World between Worlds in order to control time as well as the universe.[[217]](#cite_note-A_World_Between_Worlds-217) Following his first death, Sidious still sought ways to achieve immortality and the preservation of the Sith, as was seen by his attempt to perform a ritual on his granddaughter Rey in order to transfer his spirit into her body, which would allow Sidious to continue the Sith's legacy.[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7)

Although Sidious' reign saw a rise in [alien](/wiki/Alien "Alien") prejudice across the Empire, with [humans](/wiki/Human "Human") being the masters of the galaxy while the other species were enslaved by the Empire,[[309]](#cite_note-Rebels_Visual_Dictionary-309) Sidious was more than willing to work with aliens. During his rise to power alone, he relied on a number of them, such as the Separatist Council whom he controlled during the Clone Wars, and his political right hand, the [Chagrian](/wiki/Chagrian "Chagrian") Mass Amedda. In addition, Sidious was trained by[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) a Muun,[[310]](#cite_note-Endless-310) Darth Plagueis,[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) and his first apprentice was a Zabrak, Darth Maul.[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1) He also used General Grevious as the official commander of the Separatists once Dooku perished.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)

 [![As the Emperor, Sidious no longer needed to maintain two identities, and fully embraced his Sith persona in thought and action.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/09/SidiousSaber-ROTS.png/revision/latest?cb=20240203031612) [![As the Emperor, Sidious no longer needed to maintain two identities, and fully embraced his Sith persona in thought and action.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/09/SidiousSaber-ROTS.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20240203031612)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/09/SidiousSaber-ROTS.png/revision/latest?cb=20240203031612) 

As the Emperor, Sidious no longer needed to maintain two identities, and fully embraced his Sith persona in thought and action.

 

To those who had been at his nonexistent mercy, Sidious was known to be exceptionally sadistic, and he often took visible pleasure in torturing others.[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106) He was similarly quite bloodthirsty as well, and frequently reveled in combat to the point of laughing while he fought or killed.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106)[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15) He was also noted for his lack of forgiveness, as even Darth Vader, who was well known for summarily executing officers who failed him, considered Sidious to be even less clement than himself.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) According to [Sosha Soruna](/wiki/Sosha_Soruna "Sosha Soruna"), the reason Sidious left his homeworld of Naboo relatively untouched during his reign was because he enjoyed tormenting the populace with the fact that he could destroy the serene beauty of the planet at anytime.[[287]](#cite_note-Shattered_Empire_2-287) In spite of his exceptional mastery of the dark arts, he was no less susceptible to fear, one of the primary emotions of the dark side, than any other Sith: after being attacked by a powerful [Force push](/wiki/Force_push "Force push") from Yoda, he displayed visible panic, attempted to flee rather than fight, and only confronted his opponent when he appeared to have no other choice.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Despite this, his passion to inflict pain on others and his hate were a priority to him over his own well-being: while he could have used his own powers to save himself from Darth Vader during the Battle of Endor, Sidious' hate was so strong that his only thought was to harm Vader as his apprentice carried him to his first death.[[311]](#cite_note-RotJ:BtPotDS!-311)

Unlike Darth Vader, his more conservative apprentice, Sidious believed that progress was in no way contrary to the ways of the Sith. When Vader was presented to the cyborgs created by Doctor Cylo, he denounced them as abominations and heresy to the ways of the Force. However, Sidious claimed that he was merely an apprentice and was meant to learn what he knew and that Sidious was meant to discover what there was to teach. He also dismissed Vader's hatred of technological superiority by replying that everything was of the Force.[[238]](#cite_note-Vader_6-238)

 [![Sidious orchestrated the Galactic Empire's destruction, believing it needed to fall in order to rise as a true Sith Empire.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/a/ad/Sentinel_BFII.png/revision/latest?cb=20170611031753) [![Sidious orchestrated the Galactic Empire's destruction, believing it needed to fall in order to rise as a true Sith Empire.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/a/ad/Sentinel_BFII.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20170611031753)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/a/ad/Sentinel_BFII.png/revision/latest?cb=20170611031753) 

Sidious orchestrated the Galactic Empire's destruction, believing it needed to fall in order to rise as a true Sith Empire.

 

Sidious saw the fall of the Galactic Empire as a necessary consequence of his demise; he believed that the Empire had failed to protect its Emperor, despite the vast military at its disposal, and was therefore undeserving of a future without him. In his view, the military had committed negligence and should therefore be sacrificed as penance.[[30]](#cite_note-Secrets_of_the_Sith-30) Using a game of Shah-tezh as an illustration, Sidious believed that the sole purpose for the Empire's existence was to protect his own life and well-being. He believed that the Empire was a failure if it failed to ensure the survival of its Emperor. Even before the formation of the Empire, Sidious had prepared for this fate by formulating a contingency plan. The Contingency involved luring the Empire to the barren Inner Rim planet Jakku and detonating the planet's core. The explosion would destroy both the planet and the orbiting Imperial and enemy fleets,[[79]](#cite_note-Empire's_End-79) an outcome which Sidious regarded as retribution for the Empire's failures.[[30]](#cite_note-Secrets_of_the_Sith-30) The key to the Contingency was the Jakku Observatory, which concealed a borehole that penetrated the planet's core, and [Counselor to the Empire](/wiki/Counselor_to_the_Empire "Counselor to the Empire") Gallius Rax.[[79]](#cite_note-Empire's_End-79) Decades after his death, however, Supreme Leader Snoke discovered that the Contingency planned for the Empire's rebirth, secretly constructing shipyards and laboratories in the Unknown Regions in pursuit of this goal.[[157]](#cite_note-TLJ_Expanded_Edition-157)

 [![Though confined within a flawed clone, Sidious continued to pursue his plans for power and revenge.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/8/8d/SidiousRevealsRey-TROS.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20200401082421) [![Though confined within a flawed clone, Sidious continued to pursue his plans for power and revenge.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/8/8d/SidiousRevealsRey-TROS.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20200401082421)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/8/8d/SidiousRevealsRey-TROS.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20200401082421) 

Though confined within a flawed clone, Sidious continued to pursue his plans for power and revenge.

 

Following his demise on Endor and resurrection, in spite of his physical frailness, Sidious' mind was sharper than ever before.[[280]](#cite_note-Sidious'_Body-280) Upon realizing that the Jakku scavenger Rey was his granddaughter, Sidious manipulated Kylo Ren into bringing the young woman to him in order to steal her body as a new host. While he tried to sway Rey to his side by claiming that he cared for her, Rey saw through his ruse; by sensing his thoughts, she realized that his motives were fixated purely on his own preservation, indicating that there was no good in it and what was left was pure evil. When it became clear that Rey would not submit to his ritual, Sidious unleashed his fury, trying to kill both her and a redeemed Ben Solo. It was those very same traits of arrogance and selfishness that eventually led to Sidious' final downfall, as he underestimated Rey's true potential when she uses the combined strength of all the Jedi from the past (including Vader's) to finally destroy the Sith Emperor for good. Even after experiencing death, Sidious' beliefs and way of being remained largely unchanged; his sole overriding ambitions were the attainment of unlimited power, a grand empire under his legacy and the perpetuation of a Sith Order embodied through him. He would go to any lengths to realize these goals, including harm his own progeny.[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7)

 [![Sidious' scarred and deformed visage served as a reminder of the price that he paid for unlimited power.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/4/44/EmperorsArrival-RotJAVA.png/revision/latest?cb=20250319051855) [![Sidious' scarred and deformed visage served as a reminder of the price that he paid for unlimited power.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/4/44/EmperorsArrival-RotJAVA.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20250319051855)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/4/44/EmperorsArrival-RotJAVA.png/revision/latest?cb=20250319051855) 

Sidious' scarred and deformed visage served as a reminder of the price that he paid for unlimited power.

 

Sidious was a human [male](/wiki/Gender "Gender") who stood at 1.73 to 1.78 [meters](/wiki/Meter "Meter")[[10]](#cite_note-DBPalpatine-10) and weighed 75 [kilograms](/wiki/Kilogram "Kilogram").[[11]](#cite_note-SWJB-11) Before his disfigurement, he was a slim man sporting wavy hair, a prominent nose, blue eyes, and a narrow face. By the Invasion of Naboo, his red hair was graying,[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1) and it had turned entirely silver ten years later.[[13]](#cite_note-Episode_II-13) As he became more embroiled in his plot to control the galaxy, the strain of leading a double life began to show in his face.[[312]](#cite_note-VE-312) After his duel with Windu, Sidious' visage was heavily disfigured and withered, with deathly pale, wrinkled skin, flesh sagging from his bulging forehead and around his piercing yellow eyes.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Serving as a reminder of his own weakness and mortality,[[312]](#cite_note-VE-312) as well as the price that he paid for power according to Luke Skywalker,[[153]](#cite_note-Secrets_of_the_Jedi-153) the change further fueled his hatred of the Jedi.[[312]](#cite_note-VE-312) His voice was altered to a degree as well, becoming deeper and taking on an edge that many found to be sinister. Tarkin, however, was of the opinion that Sidious' voice merely sounded strained when compared to that of his pre-war persona.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15)

For most of his reign, the Emperor remained away from public view and crafted holograms or idealized portraiture that depicted him in his prime, as he was in the last years of the Galactic Republic.[[148]](#cite_note-SWP-148) Even so, as the reign of the Empire solidified, the citizenry of the galaxy largely forgot the name of "Palpatine," and the man was known simply as "the Emperor."[[313]](#cite_note-longgame-313) When he was discovered on Exegol, Sidious, inhabiting a clone body, appeared to be in a putrid and decaying state. His face appeared similar to what it was prior to his original body's disfigurement, but his skin was more pallid than it was before the transfer, his eyes were white, his lips were blackened, and his fingers had begun to rot away, exposing the bone underneath. Upon draining Rey and Ben Solo of their life energy to restore his own, his appearance more closely resembled what he looked like before his first death.[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7)

## Powers and abilities

:   "*Do not underestimate the powers of the Emperor, or suffer your father's fate, you will.*"
:   ―Yoda, to Luke Skywalker[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4)

### Force abilities

#### Source of power

:   "*Hate* has *made you* stronger*. But I* remain*… your* master*. Because I* thrive *on your hate. The more* you *hate me… the more* any *of them hate me… the stronger I become.*"
:   ―Darth Sidious explains his strength to Darth Vader[[314]](#cite_note-DV_2020_40-314)

As the Dark Lord of the Sith, Darth Sidious possessed an extremely powerful connection to the Force that allowed him to use various Force powers that were beyond the abilities of even the most powerful Jedi Masters.[[32]](#cite_note-SWEYoda-32) For this he was considered to be one of the most powerful Force-users in galactic history.[[315]](#cite_note-Lightsaber_Collection-315) According to Sidious, his power in the dark side came from hatred, which he claimed to turn into power instead of suffering.[[316]](#cite_note-DV_2020_33-316) However, his power in the dark side took fuel from more than just personal hatred;[[314]](#cite_note-DV_2020_40-314) Sidious was able to use the fear[[317]](#cite_note-DV_2020_41-317) and hate of others as fuel for his own strength, particularly hate that was directed at himself. As he told Vader during one of his apprentice's rebellions, he thrived off the hatred burning off of Vader. If Vader or anyone else grew in how much they hated the Emperor, those feelings would serve to make Sidious stronger in the dark side: in effect, Vader's efforts to become stronger by increasing his hate for Sidious strengthened his master.[[314]](#cite_note-DV_2020_40-314)

Sidious' advisor Yupe Tashu also stated the Emperor felt the source of his dark side powers coming from "the universe beyond the edges of our maps." In search of what Tashu called "the source of the dark side," Sidious sent people out into the unknown space, where they established communication stations and laboratories, over the course of many years.[[156]](#cite_note-Aftermath-156)

#### Force powers

:   "*Everything is proceeding as I have foreseen.*"
:   ―Darth Sidious — ![20?cb=20250116042720](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/ee/Quote-audio.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/20?cb=20250116042720) [Link](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/02/AsIHaveForeseen-ROTJ.flac/revision/latest?cb=20250408140230)▶️ ([file info](/wiki/File:AsIHaveForeseen-ROTJ.flac "File:AsIHaveForeseen-ROTJ.flac"))[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4)

 [![Sidious was a master practitioner of Force lightning, a dark side power used to torture, disfigure, and kill one's victims.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/e7/DarthSidious-SWGoH.png/revision/latest?cb=20201114053648) [![Sidious was a master practitioner of Force lightning, a dark side power used to torture, disfigure, and kill one's victims.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/e7/DarthSidious-SWGoH.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20201114053648)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/e7/DarthSidious-SWGoH.png/revision/latest?cb=20201114053648) 

Sidious was a master practitioner of Force lightning, a dark side power used to torture, disfigure, and kill one's victims.

 

Among the abilities Sidious would use was Force lightning, which he used as both as a deadly attack[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) and as a means of [torture](/wiki/Torture "Torture").[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) On several occasions on Ryloth, he utilized blasts of Force lightning powerful enough to not have only killed the lyleks he was attacking on contact, but also badly char and scorch their carapaces, which were tough enough to repel heavy blaster fire. On another occasion, he used the ability to damage a Twi'lek freighter's engines badly enough as to be able to easily pull it out of the sky with telekinesis.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178) Sidious could use Force lightning in a number of ways, including striking multiple enemies at once, with the bolts jumping from one victim to the other, like a chain, and imbuing the ground around a victim's feet with energy, effectively electrocuting them. His Force lightning's raw power was demonstrated to be far greater than that of Dooku's; while Yoda was able to effortlessly absorb and deflect Dooku's lightning, he was only able to partially deflect Sidious'. Another more obscure ability that he possessed was the power to produce a [Dark Aura](/wiki/Dark_Aura "Dark Aura"), a miniature storm of malevolent Force energy that slowed the movement of and tortured all that it caught within its radius.[[284]](#cite_note-Battlefront_II-284) A greater potential of Sidious' Force lightning, however, was achieved before his final death on Exegol; when restored back to his former self, Sidious unleashed an immense wave of Force lightning towards the sky which rapidly expanded enough to disable all the 14,000 ships of the Resistance and The Galaxy Fleet.[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7)

 [![Sidious demonstrated his prowess at telekinesis during his battle with Yoda.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/b/b1/DunMoch.png/revision/latest?cb=20130205052714) [![Sidious demonstrated his prowess at telekinesis during his battle with Yoda.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/b/b1/DunMoch.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20130205052714)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/b/b1/DunMoch.png/revision/latest?cb=20130205052714) 

Sidious demonstrated his prowess at telekinesis during his battle with Yoda.

 

He was also highly skilled with telekinesis; during his duel with Yoda,[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) during which the two were equally matched,[[59]](#cite_note-CVD-59) Sidious levitated several Senate pods simultaneously, including the one he was standing on, with great dexterity and accuracy.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Likewise, he was skilled enough with telekinesis that he was also able to remove Luke Skywalker's handcuffs while barely having to lift even a finger when they met face to face on the second Death Star.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) Sidious was capable of unleashing a Force push strong enough to easily send Maul and Opress flying and he was able to keep them pinned with little effort. He later effortlessly slammed Maul into the ground and walls, badly wounding him. Sidious was also highly skilled with Force choke. When he arrived on Mandalore, he was effortlessly able to telekinetically throttle two Mandalorians to death at once and used this power on two others while standing on the other side of the room that they were in.[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106) He was even able to use his abilities on a target from hundreds of light years away, using only a holo-transmission to show him his target, allowing him to telekinetically choke and pick up Count Dooku and open the handcuffs of Bridger while projecting himself to their respective locations through the use of a hologram.[[49]](#cite_note-TLO-49)[[221]](#cite_note-FRAF-221) Shortly after his new apprentice was reconstructed as a [cyborg](/wiki/Cyborg "Cyborg"), Sidious managed to protect himself against Vader’s force choke but Vader threw the Emperor against the wall, but Sidious managed to convince Vader to let him go. After Vader did, Sidious shocked his apprentice with bolts of [Force lightning](/wiki/Force_lightning "Force lightning"). Sidious then ignited his lightsaber and threatened that if Vader touched him with the Force again, he would finish what Obi-Wan could not.[[318]](#cite_note-Darth_Vader_12-318)

Among Darth Sidious' most powerful abilities was being able foresee the future, an ability which allowed him to plan for nearly any contingency.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178) He believed that, with enough time and practice, he would eventually have been able to use the dark side to view the future with infallible accuracy.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15)

The Dark Lord also was proficient in Sith magic, as he was able to cast a Dark illusion on Yoda using a ritual that applied Balc speech incantations and managed to access the World between Worlds using an unknown ritual. He was also capable of using Sith magic to generate a blue fiery energy, which he used to attack Ezra Bridger and Ahsoka Tano, that he could use both as a weapon and a tool in order to bind and draw someone closer, as it did with Bridger; the energy wrapping around his leg became akin to a tangible rope.[[217]](#cite_note-A_World_Between_Worlds-217) He was also knowledgeable in the ancient Sith tongue, [ur-Kittât](/wiki/Ur-Kitt%C3%A2t "Ur-Kittât").[[39]](#cite_note-Sacrifice-39) The Dark Lord was also adept in the use of [Force Persuade](/wiki/Mind_trick "Mind trick") to such an extent that he was able to take complete control of a subject's mind and force them to obey his commands.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178)

 [![Through the dark side, Sidious was able to drain power from the dyad of Ben Solo and Rey, restoring his clone vessel to full strength.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/9/99/Force_drained_by_Sidious.png/revision/latest?cb=20200410073238) [![Through the dark side, Sidious was able to drain power from the dyad of Ben Solo and Rey, restoring his clone vessel to full strength.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/9/99/Force_drained_by_Sidious.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20200410073238)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/9/99/Force_drained_by_Sidious.png/revision/latest?cb=20200410073238) 

Through the dark side, Sidious was able to drain power from the dyad of Ben Solo and Rey, restoring his clone vessel to full strength.

 

Likewise, Sidious was also capable of using Dark Absorption.[[319]](#cite_note-SW:FC-319) He was also capable of telepathically communicating with Darth Vader over a distance of hundreds of light-years. It appeared, however, as though this ability may have been limited to sending and receiving relatively simple messages such as Vader requesting that a starfighter be shipped to him, as the two Sith Lords communicated through holoprojections while discussing more complex matters.[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15) Sidious also had a remarkably keen ability to sense the thoughts and feelings of others, including those of incredibly powerful Force adepts such as Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178)[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) On a related note, he was also capable of hiding his own thoughts and feelings from even such individuals as Yoda, and managed to conceal his true dark nature from the entire Jedi Council for decades before deliberately revealing himself.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Sidious also used [Force Dash](/wiki/Force_Dash "Force Dash") and could move as fast as a "lightning strike".[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178) He had the ability to drain the life force of other Force-sensitives such as Ben Solo and Rey, a dyad that he overpowered in the Force despite the physically weakened state of his cloned body. After restoring his strength with the dyad's energy, Sidious demonstrated his proficiency in telekinesis by lifting Solo and throwing him into a chasm.[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7)

### Lightsaber skills

:   "*Despite being highly trained in the art of combat by my master, I rarely used these weapons. I preferred to call upon the infinite power of the dark side to win my battles. Yet when the time came to reveal my true nature, few could survive the fury of my blades.*"
:   ―Darth Sidious[[30]](#cite_note-Secrets_of_the_Sith-30)

 [![Sidious possessed considerable skill in the art of lightsaber combat.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/7/75/DarthSidious-Platinum2023.png/revision/latest?cb=20251224235729) [![Sidious possessed considerable skill in the art of lightsaber combat.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/7/75/DarthSidious-Platinum2023.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20251224235729)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/7/75/DarthSidious-Platinum2023.png/revision/latest?cb=20251224235729) 

Sidious possessed considerable skill in the art of lightsaber combat.

 

Darth Sidious was a highly skilled swordsman, having been well trained in the art of [lightsaber combat](/wiki/Lightsaber_combat "Lightsaber combat") by his master Darth Plagueis. Although he favored his power in the dark side as his principle form of attack instead of his lightsabers, Sidious attested that only a few individuals were able to survive against his skill with the blade.[[30]](#cite_note-Secrets_of_the_Sith-30) He had an extremely aggressive, rage-fueled dueling style and augmented his swordplay by using Force-enhanced speed, which allowed him to kill three experienced Jedi Masters at once within seconds.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) He utilized a violently ferocious yet extremely fluid fighting style during his fight with Maul and Savage Opress, holding off the Sith brothers on equal grounds and ultimately separating them by stunning Maul for a brief time with the Force before toying with and killing Opress.[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106) His style was a combination of brutal aggression, extreme speed, and lethal precision.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Kit Fisto, a Jedi Master who specialized in combat, was unprepared for the ferocity of Sidious' attack and consequently cut down by the Sith's lightsaber.[[320]](#cite_note-Kit_Fisto_DB-320)

 [![Sidious was as deadly with a single lightsaber as he was with dual sabers.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/3/34/PalpatinesLightsaber-Convergence.png/revision/latest?cb=20190809022723) [![Sidious was as deadly with a single lightsaber as he was with dual sabers.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/3/34/PalpatinesLightsaber-Convergence.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20190809022723)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/3/34/PalpatinesLightsaber-Convergence.png/revision/latest?cb=20190809022723) 

Sidious was as deadly with a single lightsaber as he was with dual sabers.

 

Sidious was able to fight alone against multiple opponents at once, such as the brothers Maul and Opress,[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106) as well as several members of the Jedi High Council.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) Being proficient in the style of [Jar'Kai](/wiki/Jar%27Kai "Jar'Kai"), he wielded two lightsabers during an intense duel in which he killed Opress and disarmed Maul.[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106) While skilled in dual-wielding lightsabers, Sidious was also adept with a single blade which he used against four Jedi Masters, and later Grand Master Yoda. Upon revealing his true identity to the Jedi, Sidious dispatched three Jedi Masters with haste, killing Agen Kolar and Saesee Tiin with a single blow each, before striking down Kit Fisto only moments later. Unlike the Jedi who fell to Sidious' blade, Mace Windu was able to fight the Dark Lord of the Sith on equal grounds for an extended period of time before ultimately disarming Sidious of his weapon with a kick to the Sith Lord's face.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) The duel between Sidious and Yoda, both of whom were masters of the Force, was an intense battle in which the Dark Lord ultimately prevailed,[[321]](#cite_note-Yoda_BioGal13-321) albeit with the use of his Force powers rather than a lightsaber.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)

During a sparring match, Sidious was able to quickly overpower his apprentice Darth Vader and knock Vader's lightsaber out of his hand without much effort.[[322]](#cite_note-The_Lesson_DV-322) He was also skilled in blaster deflection, as he was able to easily deflect every single blaster shot aimed at him when he fought on Ryloth.[[178]](#cite_note-LOTS-178) Soon before the [Battle at Amaxine Station](/wiki/Battle_at_Amaxine_Station "Battle at Amaxine Station"), Sidious used his lightsaber to once again spar with his apprentice while conversing about [Qi'ra](/wiki/Qi%27ra "Qi'ra") and her [plans](/wiki/War_against_the_Sith "War against the Sith") to destroy the Sith. In their sparing duel Vader manage to last longer than last time.[[323]](#cite_note-Hidden_Empire_4-323)

## Equipment

:   "*Before I was confined to this imperfect form, I possessed a pair of exquisite lightsabers, constructed from the rare metals phrik and aurodium.*"
:   ―Darth Sidious[[30]](#cite_note-Secrets_of_the_Sith-30)

 [![Darth Sidious' lightsabers were made of phrik and aurodium.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/5d/SidiousSaber-SWBoL.png/revision/latest?cb=20230806204552) [![Darth Sidious' lightsabers were made of phrik and aurodium.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/5d/SidiousSaber-SWBoL.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/250?cb=20230806204552)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/5d/SidiousSaber-SWBoL.png/revision/latest?cb=20230806204552) 

Darth Sidious' lightsabers were made of phrik and aurodium.

 

During the Naboo Crisis, Sidious wore an elaborate blue [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak"). As Supreme Chancellor, he wore golden [robes](/wiki/Clothing "Clothing") with a [velvet](/wiki/Velvet "Velvet") overcloak in the days surrounding the Battle of Geonosis and a dark crimson gigot-sleeved robe in the final days of the Clone Wars. As he rose to power he wore cloaks more fitting with Sith traditions, although without lessening his taste in lavish and comfortable fabrics. When declaring himself Emperor, Sidious wore a red robe patterned with emblems reminiscent of the [serpents](/wiki/Snake "Snake") of the planet Moraband. As Galactic Emperor, he later wore a black [zeyd cloth](/wiki/Zeyd_cloth "Zeyd cloth") robe with a hood to hide his disfigured face. He used two identical lightsabers.[[312]](#cite_note-VE-312)

## Behind the scenes

### Conception

 [![Concept art of Darth Sidious by ](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/f4/MCQ-emperor.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20070809122835) [![Concept art of Darth Sidious by ](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/f4/MCQ-emperor.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/225?cb=20070809122835)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/f4/MCQ-emperor.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20070809122835) 

Concept art of Darth Sidious by [Ralph McQuarrie](/wiki/Ralph_McQuarrie "Ralph McQuarrie")

 

From the very beginning of the writing process on the [1977](/wiki/1977 "1977") original *[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")* film [*Star Wars*: Episode IV *A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope"), director [George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas") had in mind the character that would eventually develop into the currently known Emperor. One of the earliest documents regarding the project is a paper dating to early [1973](/wiki/1973 "1973"), which compiled a list of names to potentially use in the story. At the very top of this list appeared the name "Emperor Ford Xerxes XII," as Xerxes was a historical Persian king who was assassinated by his own son, and would be then changed to "Alexander Xerxes XII," then "Emperor of Decarte." None of these mentioned names would be used ultimately.[[324]](#cite_note-The_Making_of_Star_Wars:_The_Definitive_Story_Behind_the_Original_Film-324) In the [rough draft](/wiki/The_Star_Wars_rough_draft "The Star Wars rough draft") of the script for [*A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope"), the [Emperor](/wiki/Emperor_(The_Star_Wars) "Emperor (The Star Wars)") is identified as [Cos Dashit](/wiki/Cos_Dashit "Cos Dashit").[[325]](#cite_note-Rough_Draft-325)

The [novelization](/wiki/Star_Wars:_A_New_Hope_(novelization) "Star Wars: A New Hope (novelization)") of *A New Hope* describes Palpatine as a weak-willed Senator with delusions of grandeur who was elevated first to President of the Republic and then Emperor, controlled by the Imperial bureaucracy, conformed by ministers like Wilhuff Tarkin. However, he was neither a Force user nor a great political strategist.[[326]](#cite_note-ANH_novelization-326) This concept was superseded by *The Empire Strikes Back*, which revealed Palpatine to be the mastermind of the events of the *Star Wars* saga. Although *The Empire Strikes Back* made his Force connection and that he's Darth Vader's master clear,[[17]](#cite_note-Episode_V-17) his Sith affiliation (as opposed to just being a dark side user) was first showcased in Legends in [*Empire's End* 2](/wiki/Empire%27s_End_2 "Empire's End 2"), where he asks the ghosts of past Dark Lords of the Sith for help,[[327]](#cite_note-Empire's_End_2-327) and then *The Phantom Menace* revealed that he was a Dark Lord of the Sith.[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1)

In the [original trilogy](/wiki/Original_trilogy "Original trilogy"), specifically [1983](/wiki/1983 "1983")'s [*Star Wars*: Episode VI - *Return of the Jedi*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VI_Return_of_the_Jedi "Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi"), the character was never identified by his surname "Palpatine" or his Sith alter ego "Darth Sidious" on-screen, as he was referred just as "The Emperor" by most characters or "Master" by Darth Vader.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) The Emperor's surname was supplied in supplementary materials, including the [novelization](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Return_of_the_Jedi_(novelization) "Star Wars: Return of the Jedi (novelization)") for *Return of the Jedi*.[[328]](#cite_note-ROTJ_novelization-328) It wasn't until the [1999](/wiki/1999 "1999") film, [*Star Wars*: Episode I *The Phantom Menace*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_I_The_Phantom_Menace "Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace"), that both his surname and Sith alter ego were first mentioned on-screen.[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1)

Throughout the original *Star Wars* saga films, the character was referred to as either Palpatine or Darth Sidious. The character was not given a full name in any canonical or [*Star Wars* Legends](/wiki/Star_Wars_Legends "Star Wars Legends") source until [2014](/wiki/2014 "2014"), when the character's first name—Sheev—was revealed in the canon novel [*Tarkin*](/wiki/Tarkin_(novel) "Tarkin (novel)") by author [James Luceno](/wiki/James_Luceno "James Luceno").[[15]](#cite_note-Tarkin-15) However, according to Luceno in an interview with the podcast *Full of Sith*, the name was reportedly created by George Lucas for the *[Star Wars: Underworld](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Underworld "Star Wars: Underworld")* TV show that he planned to make before budget constraints, his semi-retirement, and [Lucasfilm](/wiki/Lucasfilm "Lucasfilm")'s buyout by The Walt Disney Company prevented him to do so.[[329]](#cite_note-Full_of_Sith_Luceno_interview-329) [Leland Chee](/wiki/Leland_Chee "Leland Chee") has stated that Darth Sidious' name may have derived from the word "insidious."[[330]](#cite_note-Chee-330)

### Inspiration and creation

George Lucas compared the story of Darth Sidious to real-life individuals such as [Julius Caesar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julius_Caesar "wikipedia:Julius Caesar"), [Napoleon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napoleon "wikipedia:Napoleon"), [Adolf Hitler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "wikipedia:Adolf Hitler"), [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "wikipedia:Benito Mussolini"), [Joseph Stalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "wikipedia:Joseph Stalin"), [Ferdinand Marcos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos "wikipedia:Ferdinand Marcos"), and [Alberto Fujimori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberto_Fujimori "wikipedia:Alberto Fujimori"). All of them used methods similar to the Emperor's while turning their respective democracies into personal dictatorships in real life. The Adolf Hitler similarities are particularly evident from Palpatine's position as Chancellor and the use of emergency powers to cement his hold on the waning Republic as well as his passion for art.[[331]](#cite_note-World_War_to_the_Empire-331) Palpatine's consolidation of power is also similar to Roman Emperor [Augustus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustus "wikipedia:Augustus"), the heir to Casear.[[332]](#cite_note-SW_and_History-332)

[Richard Nixon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Nixon "wikipedia:Richard Nixon") was used as the primary political model for the Emperor,[[333]](#cite_note-MakeROTJ-333) both because his presidency was known as the [Imperial Presidency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Presidency "wikipedia:Imperial Presidency"), plus the constitutional crisis caused by the [Watergate Scandal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watergate_scandal "wikipedia:Watergate scandal").[[334]](#cite_note-Secret_History_of_Star_Wars-334)[[335]](#cite_note-Episode_III_Director_Commentary-335) Lucas, in fact, created the first *Star Wars* film as an anti-[Vietnam War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam_War "wikipedia:Vietnam War") message, implying that the Empire was what America could have been, had it won the war ten years before 1973.[[336]](#cite_note-Nixonian_gangsters-336) Lucas opined, however, that Vice President [Dick Cheney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dick_Cheney "wikipedia:Dick Cheney") was actually closer to Darth Sidious.[[337]](#cite_note-337)

 [![Death, from The Seventh Seal](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/c3/Death.png/revision/latest?cb=20200324115854) [![Death, from The Seventh Seal](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/c3/Death.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/160?cb=20200324115854)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/c3/Death.png/revision/latest?cb=20200324115854) 

Death, from *The Seventh Seal*

 

In addition, film critic [Roger Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Ebert "wikipedia:Roger Ebert") and film historian [Robin Wood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_Wood_(critic) "wikipedia:Robin Wood (critic)") noted that Darth Sidious' appearance resembled Death from the [1957](/wiki/1950s#1957 "1950s") epic historical film, [*The Seventh Seal*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Seventh_Seal "wikipedia:The Seventh Seal")[[338]](#cite_note-Ebert-338) and [Queen Grimhilde's](https://disney.fandom.com/wiki/The_Evil_Queen "w:c:disney:The Evil Queen") witch form in the Disney's [1937](/wiki/1930s#1937 "1930s") animated film, [*Snow White and the Seven Dwarves*](https://disney.fandom.com/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs "w:c:disney:Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs").[[339]](#cite_note-339) George Lucas himself said that where realistically, and originally, Darth Sidious appeared in a dark color, the Dark Lord of the Sith was brightened-up in post-production to the extent where he became a white-faced figure that resembles Death, a fittingly spooky look desired by Lucas himself.[[340]](#cite_note-HTW-SW-340)

*Star Wars* author and historian [Chris Kempshall](/wiki/Chris_Kempshall "Chris Kempshall"), who would go onto analyze Palpatine and his empire from an in-universe perspective through his [2024](/wiki/2024 "2024") book *[Star Wars: The Rise and Fall of the Galactic Empire](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Rise_and_Fall_of_the_Galactic_Empire "Star Wars: The Rise and Fall of the Galactic Empire")*,[[22]](#cite_note-RiseFall-22) analyzed Palpatine, and the *Star Wars* franchise as a whole, from a historical perspective in his 2022 book *The History and Politics of Star Wars*. Within, Kempshall connected Palpatine's Operation: Cinder contingency to burn down the Galactic Empire in the event of his demise to Hitler's actions at the close of World War II, pointing out how Hiter had adopted a policy of forcing everyone within the German capital of Berlin to "share in his suicide." Further, he connected Operation Cinder to Hitler's [Nero Decree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nero_Decree "wikipedia:Nero Decree") aimed against Germany's own infastructure.[[341]](#cite_note-PoliticsofSW-341)

### Ian McDiarmid on Palpatine

:   "*There's a moment in one scene of the new film where tears almost appear in his eye. These are crocodile tears, but for all those in the movie, and perhaps watching the movie itself, they'll see he is apparently moved — and of course, he is. He can just do it. He can, as it were, turn it on. And I suppose for him, it's also a bit of a turn-on — the pure exercise of power is what he's all about. That's the only thing he's interested in and the only thing that can satisfy him — which makes him completely fascinating to play, because it is an evil soul. He is more evil than the devil. At least Satan fell — he has a history, and it's one of revenge. But the Emperor — well, I don't know all the details, but who does of the Sith? — is an independent agent who just lives for the exercise of power. He doesn't know what scruples are, let alone have any. The only emotion that manifests itself truly is the one seen just before he meets his end, if that's what he meets, in* Jedi *— and then that's pure anger, when he realizes that he hasn't succeeded in manipulating young Skywalker. So he has to kill him, and he tries to do that with unadulterated fury.*"
:   ―Ian McDiarmid on Palpatine in 2002[[342]](#cite_note-Exercise_of_Power-342)

Darth Sidious, namely the Emperor at that time, was mentioned in *A New Hope*.[[130]](#cite_note-Episode_IV-130) The Emperor first appeared in the [1980](/wiki/1980 "1980") sequel [*Star Wars*: Episode V *The Empire Strikes Back*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_V_The_Empire_Strikes_Back "Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back"), played by the experienced actress [Marjorie Eaton](/wiki/Marjorie_Eaton "Marjorie Eaton").[[17]](#cite_note-Episode_V-17) In *Return of the Jedi*, the Emperor was played by [Ian McDiarmid](/wiki/Ian_McDiarmid "Ian McDiarmid"). McDiarmid then reprised the role for the three films of the prequel trilogy, as well as in *The Rise of Skywalker* in the sequel trilogy.[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1)[[13]](#cite_note-Episode_II-13)[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)[[7]](#cite_note-Episode_IX-7) Speaking about Palpatine in promotion for the prequel film [*Star Wars*: Episode II *Attack of the Clones*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_II_Attack_of_the_Clones "Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones"), McDiarmid stated Palpatine was more evil than the [Abrahamic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abrahamic_religions "wikipedia:Abrahamic religions") figure [Satan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satan "wikipedia:Satan") because "at least Satan fell." Whereas the Abrahamic Devil is a figure who fell from grace and thus has a motivation in wanting revenge, McDiarmid—while unsure of the full story behind Palpatine due to the secrecy surrounding the Sith Order—defined Palpatine as an "independent agent" whose only motivation was to exercise power. Whereas Satan could be written as both evil and sympathetic, as he noted writer [John Milton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Milton "wikipedia:John Milton") accomplished by depicting the Devil as a tormented soul in the epic poem *[Paradise Lost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradise_Lost "wikipedia:Paradise Lost")*, McDiarmid believed Palpatine never "fell" and instead thought of the future Galactic Emperor as someone who was "evil from birth."[[342]](#cite_note-Exercise_of_Power-342)

He further defined Palpatine as "an evil soul" and someone who did not have scruples, not that Palpatine knew what scruples were in the first place. In his view, the only thing that could satisfy Palpatine was the "pure exercise of power," and he stated the character's only true emotion was "pure anger." McDiarmid pointed to Palpatine's demise in *Return of the Jedi* as proof, noting how his character showcased nothing but rage when he fails to turn Luke Skywalker to the dark side of the Force. With that failure, he cited, Palpatine believed the young Jedi had to die and tried to do so with a level of "unadulterated fury."[[342]](#cite_note-Exercise_of_Power-342) In [2023](/wiki/2023 "2023"), McDiarmid, while acknowledging his past remarks, theorized Palpatine had a "complicated" childhood and that he had indeed been twisted to evil, pondering if "various things" had "twisted him into the way that he wanted." He defined Palpatine as someone "who had to win," remarking that "the word loser" would likely be "the worst thing he could ever hear," which he compared to "a certain contemporary politician."[[343]](#cite_note-Sequel_Villains-343)

### *The Empire Strikes Back*

 [![Marjorie Eaton as the Emperor in the pre-DVD version of The Empire Strikes Back](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/ee/Emperor_TESB_1980.png/revision/latest?cb=20170129211936) [![Marjorie Eaton as the Emperor in the pre-DVD version of The Empire Strikes Back](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/ee/Emperor_TESB_1980.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20170129211936)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/ee/Emperor_TESB_1980.png/revision/latest?cb=20170129211936) 

Marjorie Eaton as the Emperor in the pre-DVD version of *The Empire Strikes Back*

 

For *The Empire Strikes Back*, the Emperor was portrayed by Eaton as a holographic image with test shots done by actress [Elaine Baker](/wiki/Elaine_Baker "Elaine Baker").[[344]](#cite_note-Making_of_Empire_note-344) The mask worn by Eaton was sculpted by [Phil Tippett](/wiki/Phil_Tippett "Phil Tippett") and applied by [Rick Baker](/wiki/Rick_Baker "Rick Baker"),[[345]](#cite_note-Emperor_tweet-345) Elaine's husband. Eaton's face was then composited with an image of a chimpanzee for the eyes[[346]](#cite_note-Making_of_ESB-346) and the voice was provided by New Zealand actor [Clive Revill](/wiki/Clive_Revill "Clive Revill").

In the [2004](/wiki/2004 "2004") DVD release of *The Empire Strikes Back*, Eaton was digitally replaced by McDiarmid, and the scene was re-shot to include new dialogue provided by McDiarmid and [James Earl Jones](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones"). This re-shoot was shot during the production of the [2005](/wiki/2005 "2005") film, [*Star Wars*: Episode III *Revenge of the Sith*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith"), which McDiarmid had a starring role in.[[17]](#cite_note-Episode_V-17)

### *Return of the Jedi* and the prequels

In the draft script for *Return of the Jedi*, when Palpatine fired his Force lightning at Luke Skywalker, the Force spirits of Obi-Wan Kenobi and Yoda would have appeared to protect their disciple by redirecting the lightning.[[154]](#cite_note-Rewind_of_the_Jedi-154)

 [!['s costume concept art for the Emperor in Return of the Jedi](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/cf/Palpatine_concept.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20100516010854) [!['s costume concept art for the Emperor in Return of the Jedi](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/cf/Palpatine_concept.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20100516010854)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/c/cf/Palpatine_concept.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20100516010854) 

[Nilo Rodis-Jamero](/wiki/Nilo_Rodis-Jamero "Nilo Rodis-Jamero")'s costume concept art for the Emperor in *Return of the Jedi*

 

For *Return of the Jedi*, the role of the Emperor was to be played by veteran thespian [Alan Webb](/wiki/Alan_Webb "Alan Webb"), who was 75 years old at the time. However, as filming was about to commence, Webb fell ill due to the record cold [England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England "wikipedia:England") was experiencing at the time. He wrote a letter to the director [Richard Marquand](/wiki/Richard_Marquand "Richard Marquand"), saying that he was very sorry, but that he felt the part was too big for him, shortly dying afterward on [June 22](/wiki/June_22 "June 22"), [1982](/wiki/1982 "1982"). English actor [Ben Kingsley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Kingsley "wikipedia:Ben Kingsley") read then for the role but was considered "very English" for playing the Emperor. With filming behind schedule, Ian McDiarmid was drafted in as a late substitute.[[333]](#cite_note-MakeROTJ-333)

For the prequel trilogy, McDiarmid reprised the role for all three films, playing a younger Chancellor Palpatine in *The Phantom Menace* and a middle-aged Palpatine in [*Star Wars*: Episode II *Attack of the Clones*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_II_Attack_of_the_Clones "Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones") and in *Revenge of the Sith*. He became at first surprised that Lucas asked him to reprise the role, as he supposed that Darth Sidious would be played by a young actor, but he accepted the offer and returned for the role once more.[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1)[[13]](#cite_note-Episode_II-13)[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12) One of the things that George told McDiarmid about playing the young Palpatine was to imagine that his face was a mask that was hiding the monster's face, which made him portray him a seemingly friendly man who was always nice to people.[[347]](#cite_note-347) Wanting to give Palpatine and Yoda's duel in *Revenge of the Sith* a more formal resolution that she felt was missing in the *Star Wars* saga itself, author [Tessa Gratton](/wiki/Tessa_Gratton "Tessa Gratton") was inspired to write the short story "[Masters](/wiki/Masters "Masters")."[[348]](#cite_note-Quest_for_Answers-348)

### *The Rise of Skywalker*

 [![Ian McDiarmid](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/fd/IanMcDiarmid.png/revision/latest?cb=20150430180009) [![Ian McDiarmid](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/fd/IanMcDiarmid.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/150?cb=20150430180009)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/f/fd/IanMcDiarmid.png/revision/latest?cb=20150430180009) 

Ian McDiarmid

 

During [Celebration Chicago](/wiki/Celebration_Chicago "Celebration Chicago") [2019](/wiki/2019 "2019"), it was officially confirmed that McDiarmid would be reprising his role as Palpatine in [*Star Wars*: Episode IX *The Rise of Skywalker*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IX_The_Rise_of_Skywalker "Star Wars: Episode IX The Rise of Skywalker"), the final installment of the [sequel trilogy](/wiki/Sequel_trilogy "Sequel trilogy") and the [*Star Wars* Skywalker saga](/wiki/Star_Wars_saga "Star Wars saga") overall, scheduled to be released on [December 20](/wiki/December_20 "December 20"), 2019. Upon the announcement, *The Rise of Skywalker* director [J.J. Abrams](/wiki/J.J._Abrams "J.J. Abrams") expressed his delight that McDiarmid's appearance on the film wasn't leaked.[[349]](#cite_note-Palpy's_Back_in_IX!-349) Producer [Kathleen Kennedy](/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy "Kathleen Kennedy") then confirmed that Palpatine's return stemmed from discussions during the development of [*Star Wars*: Episode VII *The Force Awakens*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VII_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars: Episode VII The Force Awakens")[[350]](#cite_note-Old_Idea-350) although original director [Colin Trevorrow](/wiki/Colin_Trevorrow "Colin Trevorrow") stated that the Emperor's return wasn't an idea presented in his original script for the film.[[351]](#cite_note-351)

On hinting Emperor Palpatine's comeback, McDiarmid told [Warwick Davis](/wiki/Warwick_Davis "Warwick Davis") during the panel that over the years, he has had conversations with George Lucas, who affirmed that the Emperor was definitely dead by the end of *Return of the Jedi*.[[352]](#cite_note-George's_Opinion-352) McDiarmid said he was surprised to learn during production that Sidious had created Snoke and, in effect, been responsible for every "evil action" that had happened in the Skywalker Saga.[[353]](#cite_note-Gizmodo_Palps-353) Although the film doesn't explain how Palpatine survived, editor [Maryann Brandon](/wiki/Maryann_Brandon "Maryann Brandon") has said that earlier cuts of the film had an explanation.[[354]](#cite_note-354)

### TV shows

For the [*Star Wars: The Clone Wars* film](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_(film) "Star Wars: The Clone Wars (film)")[[88]](#cite_note-TCW_film-88) and subsequent [TV show](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars "Star Wars: The Clone Wars"), Darth Sidious was voiced by veteran actor [Ian Abercrombie](/wiki/Ian_Abercrombie "Ian Abercrombie").[[90]](#cite_note-Bombad_Jedi-90) In the Creative Conservation commentary on the film's Blu-ray and audio commentary on the film's DVD, Director [Dave Filoni](/wiki/Dave_Filoni "Dave Filoni") noted that he found the fact that Palpatine and Jabba the Hutt were talking to each other fascinating. It was a character dynamic that he never thought would be seen.[[355]](#cite_note-SW:TCW_Film_Blu-ray_Commentary-355) Abercrombie passed away on [January 26](/wiki/January_26 "January 26"), [2012](/wiki/2012 "2012"), leading to actor [Tim Curry](/wiki/Tim_Curry "Tim Curry") replacing him in the final seconds of "[The Lawless](/wiki/The_Lawless "The Lawless")"[[106]](#cite_note-The_Lawless-106) as well as the remaining episodes of the series, for which he was credited, beginning the fifth season finale "[The Wrong Jedi](/wiki/The_Wrong_Jedi "The Wrong Jedi")."[[109]](#cite_note-The_Wrong_Jedi-109)

For *[Star Wars Rebels](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels "Star Wars Rebels")*, Sidious was voiced by *Star Wars* veteran [Sam Witwer](/wiki/Sam_Witwer "Sam Witwer") in "[The Siege of Lothal](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels:_The_Siege_of_Lothal "Star Wars Rebels: The Siege of Lothal")," the show's [second season](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels_Season_Two "Star Wars Rebels Season Two") premiere episode. For the [fourth and final season](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels_Season_Four "Star Wars Rebels Season Four") of the show, McDiarmid returned to provide the Emperor's voice instead, as well as subsequently re-recorded Witwer's dialogue from the second season premiere. McDiarmid returned once more to the role for *[Star Wars: Tales of the Jedi](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Tales_of_the_Jedi_(television_series) "Star Wars: Tales of the Jedi (television series)")*.

[Stuart Beattie](/wiki/Stuart_Beattie "Stuart Beattie") wrote the script for the first of three Obi-Wan Kenobi feature films. From the beginning of Beattie's story, Emperor Palpatine would tell Vader to forget Kenobi and focus on the present problems. In one scene, Palpatine sent Vader to crush a rebel uprising and he was trying to forget Kenobi. Vader later told Palpatine that Kenobi and Yoda were the two biggest threats, causing Palpatine to get angry and remind Vader of his place.[[356]](#cite_note-Vader_originally_won_battle-356) McDiarmid reprised the role for the [sixth episode](/wiki/Part_VI "Part VI") of the television series [*Obi-Wan Kenobi*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Obi-Wan_Kenobi "Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi").[[191]](#cite_note-Part_VI-191) [David Decio](/wiki/David_Decio "David Decio") was the [double](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_double_(disambiguation) "wikipedia:Body double (disambiguation)") and [stand-in](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stand-in "wikipedia:Stand-in") for McDiarmid.[[357]](#cite_note-David_Decio_Tweet-357) McDiarmid's scene was filmed against a blue screen. Director [Deborah Chow](/wiki/Deborah_Chow "Deborah Chow") wanted Palpatine to tell Vader that his obsession with Kenobi is a weakness. She told McDiarmid to film his scene between being on an edge and having some lines be more casual. McDiarmid struggled with remembering to use the word "execute" during filming.[[358]](#cite_note-Return-358)

### Deleted scenes

Palpatine's efforts to centralize power and subvert democracy initially saw a wider discussion in *Revenge of the Sith*, particularly through the "Rebel Alliance subplot."[[359]](#cite_note-A_Stirring_in_the_Senate-359) Firstly, Palpatine and Skywalker would have had a scene in the Chancellor's office where Palpatine reveals the Senate would, that afternoon, ask him to take direct control over the Jedi Council's affairs, defending the choice by saying it was another adjustment to the constitution in the name of security. While Skywalker agreed in taking power over the Council from the unfocused Senate in the name of winning the war, he warns his old friend of the Council's growing upset at constitutional changes. Claiming he had no choice but to take on the additional power, Palpatine quickly changes the conversation to his history with Skywalker before making him question the Council, claiming they see his growing power in the Force as a threat.[[360]](#cite_note-Changes_to_Constitution-360)

The Rebel Alliance subplot began with Organa and Mothma establishing the Delegation of 2,000 in the name of opposing the Chancellor's increased power. In Organa's apartment, it is noted that Palpatine has regularly passed amendments to the constitution, taken personal control over the Jedi Council, and, as of that morning, appointed governors to oversee Republic star systems, effectively subverting the Senate's authority. Although surprised that one of her oldest advisors would act in such a non-democratic manner, Amidala becomes part of the Delegation.[[359]](#cite_note-A_Stirring_in_the_Senate-359) After a meeting in Amidala's apartment, where the gathered legislators decide their new alliance would be focused on the Senate instead of going to the Jedi right away,[[361]](#cite_note-Seeds_of_Rebellion-361) Palpatine and Skywalker were confronted by a gathering of the Delegation in the Chancellor's office, where Amidala speaks on behalf of the gathered against Palpatine's conduct.[[362]](#cite_note-Confronting_the_Chancellor-362)

Cutting off [Fang Zar](/wiki/Fang_Zar "Fang Zar")'s attempt at a comment and bidding the group farewell, Palpatine continues to tempt Skywalker to the dark side by claiming the group, even Amidala, has ulterior motives and can not be trusted. Although Skywalker attempts to defend his secret wife, Palpatine pries at the conflicted Jedi's emotional armor by claiming he simply does not want to admit it is possible.[[362]](#cite_note-Confronting_the_Chancellor-362) The Delegation of the 2,000 and Palpatine's Sector Governance Decree have since been confirmed to be canon.[[128]](#cite_note-The_Rebel_Files-128) Palpatine's manipulation of Skywalker from[[140]](#cite_note-The_Long_Game-140) the Delegation meeting in Chancellor's office deleted scene[[362]](#cite_note-Confronting_the_Chancellor-362) was mentioned within "[The Long Game](/wiki/The_Long_Game:_The_Insidious_Plot_of_Sheev_Palpatine "The Long Game: The Insidious Plot of Sheev Palpatine")," an article about Palpatine's rise to power written by [Michael Kogge](/wiki/Michael_Kogge "Michael Kogge") for [*Star Wars Insider* 188](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider_188 "Star Wars Insider 188"), as a canonical quote.[[140]](#cite_note-The_Long_Game-140)

Another deleted scene sees Windu, Kenobi, and Yoda discuss Palpatine's effort to take control of the Jedi Council and whether they must move against him.[[363]](#cite_note-A_Plot_to_Destroy_the_Jedi-363) In the original story treatment for *Revenge of the Sith*, Darth Sidious was intended to reveal that he created Anakin Skywalker through the midi-chlorians, thus making him, in some way, Anakin's father,[[364]](#cite_note-I'm_Your_Father-364) although George Lucas ultimately cut this out of the film.[[365]](#cite_note-Palpatine_fatherhood_cut-365) Although Darth Sidious and/or Darth Plagueis's attempts to meddle with medichlorians is noted in the film, the idea that Sidious created Skywalker was dropped from the final cut.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)

### Debates and discrepancies

#### Visual appearances

:   "*The strain of all this exertion is what's transforming him into the Emperor that we see later in Return of the Jedi.*"
:   ―John Knoll in the [*Star Wars*: Episode III *Revenge of the Sith*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith") DVD commentary[[366]](#cite_note-DVD-366)

One known debate about Darth Sidious is his real appearance. In *Revenge of the Sith*, during his duel against Mace Windu, upon being disarmed, Sidious uses Force lightning against the Jedi Master, but he deflects it back to him, causing his face to be disfigured and scarred in the process. Later on, when Anakin cuts Windu's hand to succor Sidious, he electrocuted Windu, knocking him off the window to his death, although the Force lightning doesn't disfigure Windu for the short period of time it is used.[[12]](#cite_note-Episode_III-12)

However, previous to the Force lightning's appearance in *Revenge of the Sith*, when it first appeared in *Return of the Jedi*, Sidious used it against Luke Skywalker, and it did not disfigure or scar Skywalker.[[4]](#cite_note-Episode_VI-4) In the DVD commentary for *Revenge of the Sith*, [John Knoll](/wiki/John_Knoll "John Knoll") said, "The strain of all this exertion is what's transforming him into the Emperor that we see later in Return of the Jedi."[[366]](#cite_note-DVD-366) Similarly, [Matt Martin](/wiki/Matt_Martin "Matt Martin") of the [Lucasfilm Story Group](/wiki/Lucasfilm_Story_Group "Lucasfilm Story Group") proposed that Palpatine used a higher voltage count for his lightning when attacking Windu, or there was more going on with Palpatine, such the Sith Lord overexerting himself and causing that appearance.[[367]](#cite_note-Matt's_Explanation-367) Author [Gary M. Sarli](/wiki/Gary_M._Sarli "Gary M. Sarli") proposed in 2005 that Palpatine had been using a [Sith alchemy](/wiki/Sith_alchemy/Legends "Sith alchemy/Legends") technique known as [masking](/wiki/Mask_(Sith_Alchemy) "Mask (Sith Alchemy)") to hide his true appearance, with the Force lightning wiping the mask away. Sarli further theorized that Sidious decided to not save his mask in order to further convince Skywalker he needed to intervene and to claim he was scarred to the Senate.[[368]](#cite_note-Jedi_Counseling_71-368)

#### Other discrepancies

Sidious' height has been stated to either be 1.73 meters,[[10]](#cite_note-DBPalpatine-10)[[9]](#cite_note-SWEPalpatine-9) or 1.78 meters.[[369]](#cite_note-Character_Encyclopedia-369)[[36]](#cite_note-SWESidious-36) This article assumes the newer databank entry height on StarWars.com to be the correct height.[[10]](#cite_note-DBPalpatine-10)

In a question and answer session for [*The Clone Wars*: The Lost Missions](/wiki/The_Clone_Wars:_The_Lost_Missions "The Clone Wars: The Lost Missions"), Dave Filoni stated that Sidious had Darth Maul and Darth Tyranus as apprentices at the same time.[[47]](#cite_note-TCW_Lost_Missions_Q&A-47) However, Sidious' biography gallery in the [Databank](/wiki/Databank_(2014-) "Databank (2014-)") claimed that he recruited Dooku into the Sith during his time as Supreme Chancellor after[[282]](#cite_note-Sidious_BioGal5-282) the Invasion of Naboo.[[278]](#cite_note-Sidious_BioGal_2,_3,_and_4-278) Maul was thought to be killed during that event.[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1) However, "[The Lost One](/wiki/The_Lost_One "The Lost One")" establishes that Dooku, in some form, must have joined the Sith before *The Phantom Menace*;[[49]](#cite_note-TLO-49) Finis Valorum loses his position as Supreme Chancellor within that movie,[[1]](#cite_note-Episode_I-1) yet Dooku had Sifo-Dyas killed for the Sith Plan during Valorum's chancellery.[[49]](#cite_note-TLO-49) The *Tales of the Jedi* episode "[The Sith Lord](/wiki/The_Sith_Lord "The Sith Lord")" would address the issue directly by showing Dooku had joined Sidious by the time of *The Phantom Menace*, but he had yet to fully fall to the dark side and become Sidious' pupil until the episode's events.[[69]](#cite_note-The_Sith_Lord-69)

### Non-canon content

:   "*Why was I so mean about it? In fact, why am I always so mean?—* [gasps] *It's a Life Day miracle! Oh, that's it! That's it from now on! No more dark side! No more ruling the galaxy! Old Sheevy Palpatine is gonna change his ways—*"
:   ―Darth Sidious' final words as he falls into the reactor shaft in *[The LEGO Star Wars Holiday Special](/wiki/The_LEGO_Star_Wars_Holiday_Special "The LEGO Star Wars Holiday Special")*[[370]](#cite_note-Holiday_Special-370)

 [![Darth Sidious, in  form](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/eb/Public_enemies.png/revision/latest?cb=20200324113053) [![Darth Sidious, in  form](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/eb/Public_enemies.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/240?cb=20200324113053)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/e/eb/Public_enemies.png/revision/latest?cb=20200324113053) 

Darth Sidious, in [LEGO](/wiki/LEGO "LEGO") form

 

In the non-canon *[LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures](/wiki/LEGO_Star_Wars:_The_Freemaker_Adventures "LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures")*, Darth Sidious was voiced by [Trevor Devall](/wiki/Trevor_Devall "Trevor Devall"). In the [first season](/wiki/LEGO_Star_Wars:_The_Freemaker_Adventures_Season_One "LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures Season One"), Sidious and Darth Vader learned about the history of a powerful lightsaber called the [Kyber Saber](/wiki/Kyber_Saber "Kyber Saber"), which was made out of several kyber crystals. However, the Jedi Master who crafted the sword had deemed it too dangerous and destroyed the lightsaber before scattering all of the crystals throughout the galaxy. Seeking to destroy the galaxy in one blast, Darth Sidious attempted to collect all of the crystals. He and Vader dispatched the Sith agent [Naare](/wiki/Naare "Naare") to recover the Kyber Saber crystals. However, Naare's mission was complicated by her encounter with the Force-sensitive [Rowan Freemaker](/wiki/Rowan_Freemaker/LEGO "Rowan Freemaker/LEGO") and [his family](/wiki/Freemakers/LEGO "Freemakers/LEGO"). In an attempt to gain the crystals, Naare pretended to be a Jedi and offered to train him in the ways of the Force.[[371]](#cite_note-A_Hero_Discovered-371) Despite Sidious' efforts, the Sith Lord failed to take the Kyber Saber from Rowan, who managed to destroy the weapon.[[372]](#cite_note-Return_of_the_Kyber_Saber-372)

In the [second season](/wiki/LEGO_Star_Wars:_The_Freemaker_Adventures_Season_Two "LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures Season Two"), Darth Sidious creates an Imperial [hunter droid](/wiki/Hunter_droid/LEGO "Hunter droid/LEGO") called [M-OC](/wiki/M-OC/LEGO "M-OC/LEGO"), whom he tasks with hunting down Rowan.[[373]](#cite_note-Trouble_on_Tibalt-373) This arouses the jealousy of Darth Vader, who undermines M-OC's efforts on several occasions. Despite failing to capture the Freemakers on several occasions, M-OC manages to deflect blame by pointing out that Lord Vader obstructed his efforts to obtain an [XX-23 S-thread tracker](/wiki/XX-23_S-thread_tracker "XX-23 S-thread tracker").[[374]](#cite_note-TPATP-374) After Rowan builds a powerful starship called the [*Arrowhead*](/wiki/Arrowhead_(Freemakers) "Arrowhead (Freemakers)"), Sidious forces Vader and M-OC to work together. M-OC lures Rowan into a [trap](/wiki/Capture_of_Rowan_Freemaker "Capture of Rowan Freemaker") on [Qalydon](/wiki/Qalydon "Qalydon") but Vader outsmarts the droid and brings him to the Emperor.[[375]](#cite_note-A_Perilous_Rescue-375)

In Imperial captivity, Rowan reveals that he destroyed the Kyber Saber. Though the Emperor wants to kill Rowan, Vader convinces the Emperor that Rowan can help them find more kyber crystals to power up the second Death Star. After Vader forces Rowan to reveal the location through a mind probe, the Emperor deems that Rowan has outlived his usefulness and orders his execution. However, Rowan is [rescued](/wiki/Rescue_of_Rowan_Freemaker "Rescue of Rowan Freemaker") by his siblings. Meanwhile, M-OC rebuilds himself and steals the *Arrowhead* from the Freemakers, currying the Emperor's favor. The Emperor orders M-OC to hunt down the Freemakers.[[376]](#cite_note-Escape_from_Coruscant-376)

Following a [skirmish](/wiki/Skirmish_on_Shantipole "Skirmish on Shantipole") on Shantipole, Rowan convinces M-OC that his programming is flawed.[[377]](#cite_note-Free_Fall-377) M-OC instead deduces there is a flaw in the second Death Star and rushes to the [Endor system](/wiki/Endor_system "Endor system"). However, M-OC's warnings fall on deaf ears since the Emperor is preoccupied with Luke Skywalker. Later, M-OC is distracted when he watched the Emperor falling to his death, allowing Rowan to defeat him once and for all by plunging the Kyber Saber into the Kyber crystal mounted on M-OC's back. What ensued was an explosion that disintergrated both the Kyber Saber and M-OC.[[378]](#cite_note-ROTROTJ-378)
